<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>

scenario: Not violated under MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 because that rule specifically restricts use of <string.h> functions (memcpy, strcpy, strlen, etc.). The fragment while (0 != str[r]) does not call any <string.h> function, so it does not by itself violate 21.17. Note, however, that the loop can still read out of bounds if the caller supplies a non‑NUL‑terminated buffer (e.g. char buf[3] = {'A','B','C'}; calling the function with buf will cause access to str[3] which is out of bounds). This runtime/undefined‑behavior concern is not a direct breach of Rule 21.17 but is a correctness/safety issue that must be addressed (ensure str is NUL‑terminated or bounds-checked).
